com.hp.opencall.jmsc.test
Class ContinuityChecker

java.lang.Object
  com.hp.opencall.jmsc.test.ContinuityChecker

public class ContinuityChecker
extends java.lang.Object

This class can test the continuity between N Joinables.
The joinables are SipPhoneEmulators named "CChecker-0", "CChecker-1", etc. They are available with getPin(int).
When isContinuous is called, one the phones sends a DTMF to all others, which receive it (or not ...).
The sender also listens for DTMFs (boomerang effect).
Uses "testcase.dtmf1" to play a modulated "1".
Multiple calls to isContinuous allow to test with a different sender each time.
As an option, the first phone may be implemented by a MediaGroup, named "CChecker-MG-0". the processing is otherwise unchanged.
In some testcases documentation, the Joinables are named "sender", "receiver0", "receiver1", etc... for more clarity. The accessors getSender() and getReceiver(int i) refer to this naming.

Build a N-ways continuity checker.

Parameters:

Method Detail

getSender

public javax.media.mscontrol.join.JoinableContainer getSender()
Return the first object (pin #0).

The "Sender" naming refers to the usual case where the first object is the sender.

getReceiver

public javax.media.mscontrol.join.JoinableContainer getReceiver(int i)
Return the i+1 object (pin i+1).
The "Receiver" naming refers to the case where objects i+1,..., i+n are receivers.

getPin

public javax.media.mscontrol.join.JoinableContainer getPin(int i)

isContinuous

public boolean isContinuous(int senderIdx,
                            java.lang.Boolean[] shouldReceive)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
Perform the test.
The Sender and all Receivers must have been joined before this call.

Parameters:
senderIdx - The index of the SipPhoneEmulator that will send DTMFs
shouldReceive - An array of booleans contained expected reception status
Returns:
true or false, indicating if the test behaved as expected
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
